name: Jeux TV
keyboard: Two paddles with a knob and a button
coprocessor: Ball angle, Paddle size, Ball speed, Power on/off
description:
This is another "pong-in-a-case" system. You can easily carry this one away to play pong anywhere you want ;-) The design is very sober, only metallic and wooden parts. It looks like it has been made by hand in very limited quantities.

The system offers the classic games of the General Instrument AY-3-8500 chipset. The game selection is made through a big knob in the middle of the system. There are also some holes made in the metalic case, to let the sound of the speaker pass through.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br>  ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPTEMBER 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sharp 1211 advert from ILLEL, a french computer seller</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/" target="_blank">Soichiro's Oga</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Never before in the history of modern computers has there been available a totally portable machine with the ability to cope with so many demands, to so many people, in so many different business areas.<br> Epson, with over 20 years experience in designing and manufacturing high quality printers, have produced the HX-20, a precision machine with its own rechargeable power supply that can be used for just about any task within to days discerning business: from data capture to word processing, from card indexing to sales order entry.<br> Communicating with other machines is no problem and the HX-20 is easily coupled to one of our fine printers. You can even link in another main computer system by using an acoustic coupler.<br> Don't be fooled by its size, the HX-20 has all the software back-up you'd expect from a much larger machine and incorporates many "bigger computer" features - 16k RAM expandable to 32k with serial interfaces, a full size typewriter keyboard, it's own built in LCD screen and a dot matrix microprinter. A micro­cassette facility is available as an optional extra.<br> A complete computer that will either stand on its own or could be the obvious extension to your existing system.<br> More and more people are finding out just how big the small compact HX-20 is. Why don't you find out for yourself - you­ owe it to your business.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The TO-7/70 made the cover of french magazine Micro7 on february 1985.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPACT VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture; <br><br> <b>Diego Barizo</b> adds:<br> In the picture of the compact version of the TK3000, the joystick, a TRS-80 de luxe joystick, and the screen is quite similar to that of a flight simulator for the TRS-CoCo. Maybe they had one behind the monitor? <p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NLS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert from Non-Linear Systems, dated July, 1982 for the KAYCOMP II that was not still called KAYPRO. <br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"><b>A WORD ABOUT NLS</b><br> Non-Linear Systems, inc. is the originator of the digital voltmeter and an innovative leader in the field of electronic test equipment.<br> Organized in 1952, NLS has been a major supplier of digital voltmeters and ratiometers to large corporations in the aerospace industry. Since 1972, NLS has been consumer directed, providing small, portable multimeters, oscilloscopes, counters, frequency meters, temperature meters. And now, NLS has entered the world of computers with one though - to provide the best value in a small, business, scientific and family computer.</font><br><br> Standard software delivered with the KAYCOMP II: <br><br> - <b>CP/M 2.2</b> - operating system<br> - <b>S/BASIC</b> - Structured Basic compiler<br> - <b>PROFIT PLAN</b> - Electronic worksheet<br> - <b>SELECT</b> - Complete word processing system<br> - <b>TEACH</b> - A self-teaching guide to SELECT </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT, JAN. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Seductive Sanco computing.<br><br> Treat you to a star for less than 3,000 Euros</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>DEC Advertises its range of networking products.<p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>
